questions.question: In what order are Access Controls evaluated?
answers: A. Field-level - most specific to most general; then Table-level - most specific to most general
B. Field-level - most general to most specific; then Row-level - most specific to most general
C. Table-level - most specific to most general; then Field-level - most specific to most general
D. Table-level - most specific to most general, then Row-level - most specific to most general

comments.content: Answer is C. First table lvl after field lvl
C. Table-level - most specific to most general; then Field-level - most specific to most general
C is correct. Access controls are always evaluated table and field, and always most specific to most general (

1.Match the table and field name: x_58872_needit_needit.short_description
2. Match the parent table and field name: task.short_description
3. Match any table with the field name: *.short_description
4. Match the table and any field (wildcard): x_58872_needit_needit.*
5. Match the parent table and any field (wildcard): task.*
6. Match any table (wildcard) and any field (wildcard): *.*
C is correct. Page 429 of the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - Tokyo Edition.

From the CSA prep course

61. In what order are access controls evaluated?

First at the Table-level (Most specific to most general), then at the Field-level (most specific to most general)

questions.question: When looking at a long list of records, you want to quickly filter, to show only those which have Category of Hardware. How might you do that?
answers: A. On the Category column header, right click and select Show > Hardware
B. Right click on magnifier, type Hardware and click enter
C. On the list, locate and right click on the value Hardware, select Show Matching
D. On Breadcrumb, click > icon, type Hardware and click enter
E. Click Funnel icon, type Hardware and click enter

questions.question: When looking at a long list of records, you want to quickly filter, to show only those which have Short Description containing email. How might you do that?
answers: A. Click List Magnifier to expand column search, on Short Description, type email, click enter
B. On Search box, select text, type email, click enter
C. Click List Magnifier to expand column search, on Short Description, type *email, click enter
D. Click List Magnifier to expand column search, on Short Description, type %email, click enter

comments.content:
%email - returns records with short description ending with email
*email - returns records with short description that contains word email

A, C, and D are all correct. It just depends on whether you are looking for email as a standalone word or combined with another word. But all (A, C, D) are correct. The question indicates it wants you to pull any records where the word email is contained. In that case (again technically) D is the most correct.

It's C. With the short description you can't do "show matching" as in the previous question, you need to search for records that have the word "e-mail" in the short description. and this is done by searching "*e-mail" (wildcard e-mail) in the Short Description column.

questions.question: When importing spreadsheet data into ServiceNow, what is the first step in the process?

comments.content: Load data: Navigate to System Import Sets -> Load
1. Load data: Navigate to System Import Sets -> Load

I am with E option, this is the write one, the first step in the process of importing data is Define data source, if you go to Navigation bar and type import data set, you see the module is data source this define where the data come " fetch the data from excel to this staging source.

The Anwser is Not C because you can also create import Set instead of Select one so there is no way either of those two anwsers were correct.
It is also not D since another question(Q.322) with the excat question text doesn't have the option'Load Data', and I am pretty sure you dont load data from the beginning the data is loaded after you hit submit. So the only anwser seems right would be E "Define Data Source"
replies: no no no no no no

comments.content: Gonna have to opt for Load Data. If I already have a spreadsheet where the data is defined, what do I do next? I type Load Data in the app navigator. What next? I create an import set. What next? I choose the source of my data. Clearly the answer is D. If I wanted to start before I knew what the data was then I would select E. However, since the question states that I already have that in the form of a spreadsheet then the answer is D.

Answer is D. 

"Import Sets" Is under 
"System Import Sets > Advanced > Import Sets" 
Which if you create a new instance is "Empty" & has no way to Load Data. Import Sets only shows you the imported data sources.

Under All menu - The "Integration - Imports" drop down is called "System Import Sets" Load Data is the Module that begins an import to ServiceNow. 

After filling out the form & clicking submit it states "Next Steps...." & provides the following links. 

Import Sets - Go to the import Sets for this data load.
Loaded Data.
Create Transformation Map. 
Import Logs.

Bit naughty this one and I'd imagine these options wouldnt be the same. If you browse, you have to select "Select Import Set" before you select "Load Data" but you could also type Load Data and you could select that without selecting "Select Import Set"

I would go with C here. The Module you use to load data is indeed called "Load Data" module, but once you open it, the first thing it asks you to do is select (or create a new ) Import Set table, then you need to choose a data source, and only after you do these 2 things you can click "Submit" which Loads the data....
You have to create or select an Import Set prior to selecting the Data Source.  Once the Import set is defined you update or add the data source.

questions.question: Tables may be set up with Many to Many relationships. What is a classic example of a scenario where the tables would have many to many relationships?
answers: A. Vendors can sell multiple products; and products can be sold by multiple vendors.
B. A Task can trigger many Workflows; and a Workflow can trigger many Tasks.
C. Requests can contain many Items; and Items can be any item from the catalog.
D. A Configuration Item can belong to multiple Classes, and Classes can contain multiple Configuration Items.

comments.content: option A is the example used in the Data schema overview lesson under Additional SN fundamentals content for Sys Admins & Developers.
Can't be B as this would 1) cause a loop but also 2) it would be the workflow generating the task that triggers another (sub)flow, not the task itself. Workflow-to-task is one-to-many.
A should be the correct answer
A should be the correct answer. Workflows and tasks are not two-way (i.e. a task can trigger a workflow, but this workflow will not trigger the same task - otherwise you have a loop...)

What are examples of UI Actions, relating to Lists? (Choose four.)

comments.content: List links - List Choice - List button - List Style - List Context menus

A. List Links
B. List Choices
C. List Buttons
E. List Context Menu

A. List Links
B. List Choices
C. List Buttons
E. List Context Menu
ABCE is correct links buttons context menu

ABCE is correct, you can find it SNAF book page 435: 
https://evantage.gilmoreglobal.com/reader/books/SN-SNAF-T010-PG-E/pageid/435
ABCE are the right answers, check page 436 of the ebook to confirm

I am changing my answer :-)
"A,B,C,D,E" are all correct.  "F" is wrong. The list itself is not a UI Action.
"F" is wrong.  The list itself is not a UI Action.  "B" is sort of correct, but not, since a UI Action is a single choice, not plural "choices".
Confusing question as it uses plurals which are not part of the UI action > New record.

ABCDE

List bottom button Puts a button at the bottom of a list.
List context menu Puts an item in a list field context menu (right-click a cell in a list).
List choice Puts an item in the action choice list at the bottom of a list.
List link Puts a link in the Related Links section at the bottom of a list.
Overrides Specifies a UI action that this UI action overrides.

List bottom button	Puts a button at the bottom of a list.
List context menu	       Puts an item in a list field context menu (right-click a cell in a list).
List choice	               Puts an item in the action choice list at the bottom of a list.
List link	                        Puts a link in the Related Links section at the bottom of a list.
Overrides	               Specifies a UI action that this UI action overrides.

ABCE

UI action controls
You can create a UI action to provide any of these controls:

    A button on a form.
    A context menu item on a form that appears when you open the form context menu or right-click the form header.
    A related link in a form.
    A button in the banner on top of a list.
    A button at the bottom of a list.
    A context menu item on a list that appears when you open the list context menu or right-click the list header.
    A menu item for the action choice list at the bottom of a list.
    A related link at the bottom of a list.
https://docs.servicenow.com/en-US/bundle/tokyo-platform-administration/page/administer/list-administration/concept/c_UIActions.html

questions.question:
A Service Catalog project will involve building 80 catalog items. For each of the catalog items, the following fields will be mandatory on the forms:
• Requested for
• Requested by
• Approving manager
• Delivery instructions

All of the other variables will be specific to the individual catalog item. What features would you use when designing the catalog item form?
answers: A. Create a Variable Set Template, then apply to all of the catalog items.
B. Create one Variable Set for the four variables, then add that variable set to each of the 80 catalog items.
C. Create a Record Producer that contains the four fields; then add to the record producer related list on the Catalog Items.
D. Create a Flow Designer Action, with Variable Set Data Pill, then apply flow to all of the 80 catalog items.
E. Create an Order Guide, which includes all variables; then copy and hide variables as needed.

comments.content: B is correct based on the definition of variable set

questions.question: What access does a user need to be able to import articles to a knowledge base?

comments.content: In ServiceNow, the sn_knowledge_import role is specifically used to manage and facilitate the importing of knowledge articles into the Knowledge Base.

questions.question: When importing data from a spreadsheet, which step defines where the incoming data columns will be written in the receiving table?

comments.content:
Answer is B. 
Field Matching is the step that defines where the incoming data columns will be written in the receiving table when importing data from a spreadsheet. During the field matching step, you map the columns in the source file to the fields in the target table. This allows you to specify which columns in the source file correspond to which fields in the target table, ensuring that the data is imported correctly.

Filed Mapping is what you do in Create Transform Map

The B answer says Filed Matching not Filed Mapping...
D is correct.  Field match was never considered a step.  However Create Transform Map, is considered a step in the process.
Questions is on which "step", so i would go with: D.Create Transform Map. At transform map you can then do field matching but the "step" is D.

Can I say NONE of the above? In reality you can create a transform map record by just specifying the source and target tables and clicking submit. You need to do the firld mapping before you transform. But it's Field MAPPING not Field Matching and it's done in the Transform Map (so it has to be there) through Auto Field Map Matching or Mapping Assist links. Very confusing question...

D - Create Transform Map is the correct answer.  
B - Field Matching: For Event Management, when creating Event Rule to bind non-host CI using CI field matching, if there are multiple CI records having same name.

Answer should be Field Mapping. But we dont have that option. 
So its D because Transform Map is a set of field maps.

Wouldn't it be B if it was spelled correctly to Field Mapping? Note that not only the questions could be spelled incorrectly, I recognize that many answers are spelled incorrectly with or without purpose.

questions.question: To apply a UI Policy to all views, which field should be set to true in its definition record?

comments.content: To apply a UI Policy to all views, set the Global setting to true.
Per my PDI, "if the 'Global' checkbox is selected, the UI Policy applies to all form views; otherwise the UI Policy is view-specific".
Answer is A. If UI policy applies to extended table then answer is D. So here answer is A.

Answer is A.
Global [Advanced view]	Option for specifying whether the UI policy applies to all form views. If this check box is cleared, the UI policy is view-specific.
By default, the Global UI policy applies to all form views. However, a UI policy can be specific to a view. For example, you can define a UI policy for only the itil view of a form. Use the View field to accomplish this.
yes global makes the most sense

questions.question: Which one of the following describes the primary operations performed against tables in the ServiceNow platform?

comments.content:
Please read page 367 from the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - Tokyo booklet.
It states Create, Delete, Read, Write. 

There is no Upload. 

There is an update, as stated in answer "C" but "C" also contains "Rate" which is also incorrect. 

Trick question!

Create, Read, Write, Delete
To make it easier to remember they acronym CRUD was introduced, where U stands for Update.

But such choice is not available in AC rules, you have WRITE only.

CRUD is for ease of remembering the basic operations, but it NOT the real option available.
The correct answer is D. In ServiceNow a CRUD is named as a CRWD, Create, Read, Write and Delete, be careful and take your time to understand the question

Correct Answer is D

Choice A has "Upload" this is incorrect
Choice C has "Rate" this is incorrect

The answer is D. Please read each choice in the question carefully. CRUD / CRWD are used interchangeably. 
Create / Read / Update or Write / Delete
The screen shots proof is here

https://www.servicenow.com/community/developer-forum/crud-or-crwd/m-p/2583304
"CRUD", but the W for Write can replace the U for Update.

replies: It is A. Sorry. Create, Read, Update, Delete

comments.content: Create, Read, Update, Delete is CRUD
READ NOT RATE SO IT SHOULD BE A
C is the right answer, these operations are called CRUD
C is the right answer, these operations are called CRUD
replies: Well apologies it is not C because it should be Create, Read, Update and Delete
in ServiceNow, its CRWD. Do not confuse everyone please

questions.question: Which ServiceNow utility gives a Service Desk agent the ability to trace from a Service having an issue, to see which CIs supporting that service have active issues?

comments.content:
According to the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - Tokyo, page 427, it states, Dependency Views indicate if a CI has any active, pending issues."

I'd select A on the Exam
Answer is A per SN Fundamentals book p.361-362

A - dependency view

The CI Health Dashboard is used to look at things accuracy/completeness of CI information.
Dependency views shows the related services down to the affected cis
This is tough.  I leaning toward A because the question is relates to what a Service Desk user would use; not an Administrator.
According to the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - "it states, Dependency Views indicate if a CI has any active, pending issues."
The health dashboard provides a single view of the quality of data at the CMDB, CI class and CI levels using completeness, correctness and compliance scores

It's D, according to SNOW docs:
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/vancouver-servicenow-platform/page/product/configuration-management/task/t_ViewCIHealth.html

From ChatGPT - To trace from a service having an issue to see which CIs supporting that service have active issues, the CI Health Dashboard would be more suitable. It allows Service Desk agents to view the health status of CIs supporting a particular service and identify any active issues or incidents associated with those CIs. By analyzing the CI Health Dashboard, agents can gain insights into the affected CIs and their current status, enabling them to trace the impact of issues on the supporting CIs of a service.

While the CI Dependency View provides a visual representation of CI relationships, it may not directly provide real-time information about active issues or incidents associated with specific CIs. It focuses more on understanding the connectivity and dependencies between CIs.

D is the correct answer. 
CI Health Dashboard in ServiceNow provides IT teams with a powerful tool for managing and maintaining the health of their organization's IT infrastructure, helping to ensure that critical systems and services remain available and performing at peak efficiency.

questions.question: On the knowledge base record, which tab would you use to define which users are not able to write articles to the knowledge base?

comments.content:
The question is confusing, it seems like the correct answer would be "cannot contribute" which is not an option. If you *only* select "can read" then inherently those users can only read and not contribute. So technically this may be the correct answer 
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/quebec-servicenow-platform/page/product/knowledge-management/task/t_SelectUserCriteria.html

I think it's A. I did 2 tests. 
Knowledge > Administration > Knowledge Bases.=> open a record. 
1.Trying to add a role to both 'can read' and 'can contribute'. It worked.  
   So I think just setting 'can read' does not have full control to remove a write access. 
2.On 'Can contribute', I see we can add filter options like 'OR users does not contain xx'. 
   So this at least a way to let a user/users are NOT able to write. 
So my conclusion, either 'able to'/'not able to' is controlled in the same tab 'can contribute' for writing access. Just my opinion at the moment.
The answer choices are wrong. The answer is "cannot contribute" and it is not listed
CAN READ means they can’t contribute
Can contribute refers to users that CAN actually contribute to the article, so the answer C because can read CANNOT contribute to the attribute, they can only read

Cannot Contribute would be the perfect answer.
For this question, if we add them to Can Read, this will limit their ability to create new articles (I think).
Anyway, it;s the closest thing to correct answer

A - Can Contrbiture (because Cannot Contribute is not in the choices)

If you define can contribute, it means only the users in the criteria can write, the rest CANNOT.

Ans is  B  The "Cannot Author" tab is specifically designed to restrict users from writing or authoring articles in the knowledge base. The "Can Read" tab, on the other hand, only allows users to read the articles without making any changes.

Can Read:	Users can read knowledge articles in the knowledge base.
Cannot Read:	Users can't read knowledge articles in the knowledge base.
Can Contribute:	Users can create, modify, and retire knowledge articles in a knowledge base. Contribute access to a knowledge base also provides read access to all articles in the knowledge base.
Cannot Contribute:	Users can't create, modify, retire, or read knowledge articles in the knowledge base.
Answer is A.  On P.223 in the Vancouver study guide: User Criteria records are accessed from the Can read or Can contribute related lists.
None of these are correct. As jjjrrrferere says correct answer is "Cannot Contribute". This is a duplicate of question 123 so you can ignore this question as 123 has the Cannot Contribute option

The answer should be "cannot contribute" 
https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/utah-servicenow-platform/page/product/knowledge-management/task/t_SelectUserCriteria.html
Related list	Description
Can Read	Users can read knowledge articles in the knowledge base.
Cannot Read	Users can't read knowledge articles in the knowledge base.
Can Contribute	Users can create, modify, and retire knowledge articles in a knowledge base. Contribute access to a knowledge base also provides read access to all articles in the knowledge base.
Cannot Contribute	Users can't create, modify, retire, or read knowledge articles in the knowledge base.

Obviously the actual answer would be "Cannot Contribute", but that selection is not available as an answer here.

Therefore, with the options available to us here, the MOST correct choice would be to limit the user with "Can Read" access.

Should be can contribute. 
If the user is not on the list, then they cannot contribute

questions.question: What types of entities can receive task assignments, in ServiceNow? (Choose two.)
The Report Designer contains different sections for configuring your report. Which section is used to adjust the look of your report, including colors, titles and legend layout?

comments.content: D is correct. Page 267 of the ServiceNow Administration Fundamentals - Tokyo Edition.
Style is the correct answer. You may change the Chart title and colors.
This is not right, it should be C
replies: No sir, style apply in this specific case :)
